review_title: Poor quality university - do not attend.
pros: None, there are no pros here.
cons: Working with the U of I music school was the worst decision I have ever made on a personal or career level. The faculty does not care about you, they only want your money. You will work incredibly hard and if you face challenges, you will encounter an "it's not our fault, it's yours" attitude for any difficulties you encounter during your studies and teaching assistantship. The assistantships they provide are extremely low paid at best, non-paid at worst and they do not care about you in the slightest. For those considering the University of Idaho - do not attend. For those currently at the University of Idaho - LEAVE!

review_title: Best school in Idaho, for undergrads
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: Very strong focus on student success in course work, lots of interesting research is happening and is accessible for undergraduates. Community is lovely to live in. Campus is beautiful.
cons: Graduate students are chronically left with poor/no guidance. Intentionally or no, the focus of faculty is rarely on facilitating their success, but rather on maintaining high undergraduate course reviews. The result is under-published and burned out graduate students and reduced research output from a school that should be able to shine given it's unique resources and access to talented staff/students. Numerous grants are being lost as faculty leave for other institutions bringing key students with them.

job_title: Interlibrary Loan Supervisor in Moscow, ID

cons: Poor wages. Few opportunities to advance and grow beyond your station. Bauracracy Can be "clique" / favoritism played

pros:
I worked in the Deportment of Biological Sciences in a research lab. There are many options, however, you need to initiate them yourself. The best way to do so is email the professors early on about your interest in their lab. I did not have the best experience in my lab and was significantly overworked and underpaid. However, this is not true for all labs. I had friends that worked in different labs who were very happy with their work environment. I would recommend really paying attention to what other researchers have to say about the labs you're interested in. The university itself has a lot of opportunities, you just need to make sure you choose one that works best for you.

Getting experience, advancing skills, preparing for post-graduation career

It's a good thing I have a partner who works full time in an actual career position.

pros: Collaborative interagency project that allows for reasonable work hour flexibility. Great exposure to a variety of field techniques, hands-on work, training, and scheduling. Great job to jump into a supervisory role, beautiful field sites with opportunities to work at a variety of field sties throughout the state.
cons: Possible delays when dealing with Idaho Fish & Game employee (who has since retired), work can seem overwhelming at times BUT the project coordinator & co-coordinator are always willing and able to help where it is most needed. If you're not comfortable with cold weather and long nights (beginning of field season starts with nighttime trapping of Greater Sage-grouse in late February) or occasional high summer temps then this job is not for you.

review_title: You can chart your path and make a diffrence
pros: A gem among land grant institutions. A storied place and engaged COMMUNITY, excellent town campus partnerships. Iin a beautiful quaint town with the motto heart for the arts. Diverse and liberal oasis that is making a difference in the lives of people in the state and the world. It's small size translates into personal connections and flattened hierarchy. Check out the Borah Symposium, The Lionel Hampton Jazz Festival, the innovative community based design and research, the tribal summits, and much more.
cons: Need more state investment, however, this is a place of possibilities.

job_title: Grauduate Research Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: They pay for your tuition and if you need it, health insurance. You get your degree for free basically, but you have to work for it.
cons: Graduate Assistants are expected to work 20 hours per week during the school year and commit the other 20 hours to school work or thesis work. During the summer, graduate assistants work 40 hours/week on lab and field work, whatever their advisor needs and is necessary for your thesis. I am making about $9/hour in the summer. While working as a server years ago I at least made $10. During the semester, I am paid about $10.30/hour and am responsible for class fees and books.

review_title: Public land-grant university in a deeply conservative state
pros: Some great students, who don't know how excellent they are; beautiful setting and fun town to live in; Tenure requirements are very reasonable; wonderful colleagues.
cons: The state of Idaho generally does not support the university well, either financially or politically; the university has not managed it's budget responsibly in the past, leading to layoffs; administrators are deeply interested in bean-counting, to the detriment of the university culture; junior administrative staff are poorly paid, leading to high turnover and difficulties running a competitive research program.

review_title: From here you can go . . . . here
pros: At The University of Idaho, you'll enjoy a good degree of job security.  Once you're in the U of I system, it's very easy to stay working for the U of I.  The culture is friendly to newcomers, and there is a rich history to the University that makes for an enjoyable work experience overall.
cons: As with many universities, everything moves at a very slow pace.  Don't expect that an idea or proposed change will be implemented at the same pace it would in a private sector corporation.  Because the U of I is a state university, we are subject to the budget set by the Idaho State Board of Education - who reside in the southern half of the state while U of I is far north.  It's often difficult for the State Board to understand our needs when they are so far away geographically.

job_title: Administrative Faculty Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: Great, affordable health benefits, retirement benefits are good, beautiful campus.
cons: Human Resources is awful. Do not go to them expecting any type of help if you're having legitimate issues within your department. They will agree with you entirely, tell you that the situation must be fixed, then call your supervisor/manager as soon as you are done speaking with them. They will also completely misconstrue the entire conversation to make you look horrible!! Going to the Ombudsman is a death sentence for your employment at UI. She always wants to hold an office meeting (intervention), wherein, she agrees with everything going wrong. However, the office meeting alerts management of your "issues" with them.  My office, College of Law, immediately put me on a Professional Development Plan, which is yhe beginning step to the firing process. Neither the Ombudsman or HR did anything to assist me in keeping my job. Spotty, inadequate training. Immature, angry, supervisor.

pros: It is great to work on intellectually stimulating research projects. I also enjoy a great deal of autonomy. I am assigned projects by my supervisor, but I get to set my own project timeline and daily schedule and I get to decide how I am going to approach a given project.
cons: Job security for postdocs is generally poor and there are no guarantees that you can get a faculty job when you get done. Right now my supervisor and I must secure funding for me on a year by year basis if I am to keep my job so I am constantly submitting grant proposals and applying for other jobs in case our funding falls through. Also, on the basis of talking with postdocs at other universities, it seems that the pay for postdocs at the University of Idaho is lower than average, but the cost of living is fairly low in Moscow, ID.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Moscow, ID
pros: In Idaho, people know the Vandals. It is a very proud and widespread community, and because of that, the network is great.
cons: The admissions office is very divided and the distance between satellite campuses accentuates the poor communication  by the leadership. Big decisions that directly impact the day-to-day work are made independently, without any consultation from those on the front lines. As a result, we consistently find ourselves being reactive instead of proactive, so are constantly ill-equipped to do our job as recruiters to the best of our ability.

pros: Great professional experience and lots of creative opportunity to improve the call center's motivation and retention. Hours are excellent for students, an average of 14 hours per week, and the evening time works great for class schedules. There are bonus opportunities and excellent management experience.
cons: There are anywhere from 30-50 callers to keep track of as far as scheduling, training, and tracking. Working in a management team of 4-6 people also creates difficulty sometimes in streamlining policies and procedures. The advancement positions have high turnover as well so the call center management changes frequently.

pros: Small, connected, interwoven and integrated working environment. U of I is a small school and this offers great opportunity for one-on-one talk with professors and staff. It is different from some big schools where one might wait for days and even weeks to gain access to one's own major professor! With mainly small to moderate sized class, there is good rapport between the professors and students in the class. That is a big plus!
cons: Options could, however be limited since there is naturally a constraint to the diversity of areas of specialization. Sometimes, this is augmented by taking classes at the neighboring Washington State University (WSU) with its own accompanying stress.

pros: Having direct access to the outdoors.  The Rocky Mountains are literally out your back door.  Within a few hours you can be at trailhead and on your way to hiking your way away from everyone and everything.  The benefits at working at the university allow for ample vacation time, so you can actually enjoy living where you do.
cons: The highest paid employer in the area and HR knows it.  Don't expect more than your yearly 3% raise and limited opportunities to grow your career.  A great place to be if you are ready to retire, but I'd  look else where if you are just starting your career.

pros: Work as both an instructor for Comm 101 Public Speaking and in the Political Science deptarment as a TA for a professor. Enjoyed teaching classes as a comm instructor, I had a lot of independence, but also had resources such as a pre-made online  course module and ideas for activities and such. As a TA in Political Science, I didn't do anything. Didn't gain any skill or nothing, but a paycheck. Pays well.
cons: See above; Being a GTA can either be too demanding or not enough. Eitherway, didn't gain much skills or experiences that would help outside of academia.

review_title: Good On-Campus Jobs for the Full-Time Student
pros:
- Flexible work hours that are guaranteed to fit around your school schedule
- Employers that want to see you succeed in your job & education
- Ability to bring your laptop and homework during work shift (varies by position)
- Quality university-wide communication channels (VoIP Phone System)
cons:
- Pay is low considering the amount of security and database programs I utilize
- 24/7 desk positions may require new employees to work graveyards and holidays
- No discounts offered to student employees for tuition or on-campus living
- Many jobs require at least part-time enrollment status

pros: Decent benefits, good pay only when compared to other options in the area, beautiful campus, friendly work environment
cons: recent reclassification lowered starting pay for a lot of those coming in to the school, pay still not adequate for experience

job_title: Architecture Teaching Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: It is rewarding to help other students learn things that were also new to you only a few years ago. Plus on the personal side, it is good review for me. I also enjoy knowing I am helping the professors that have helped me so much in my education over the years.
cons: With the automatic deposit it is hard to tell what the money is for from the university, ie: is it extra loan money, scholarship money, from another job at the university, etc

job_title: Golf Sales Associate in Moscow, ID
pros: Coworkers and customers are friendly people who work hard and appreciate the work you do. The position comes with the benefit of free golf and flexible hours.
cons: No other benefits besides free golf. Idaho minimum wage is still behind so you could travel 10 minutes across the boarder and work a minimum wage paying job for almost double the pay here. The university is scrapping for money and are tight on budgets, thus it's hard to improve anything quickly.

review_title: Never got the hours in my job description.
pros: I was a full-time student at the time, so it was easy to work a couple of hours between classes.
cons: I was never appropriately trained for the job I was doing, and though my job description stated 24 hours, I was lucky to get 10.  I was finally told, "We don't have hours for you over the summer," even though the job was supposed to be year-round, but I was not laid off.  I was expected to wait 3 months until school started again to resume my pitiful 10 hours a week.

job_title: Writing Center Tutor in Moscow, ID
pros:
- healthy work culture where the employer and employees work together to provide a productive and welcoming experience for the tutees.
- got to learn tutoring skills both physically and online, as well as getting to improve one's own English and writing skills for various industries.
- diverse both in terms of tutors and tutees.
cons: - None that I could think off. Maybe the open concept of the center where it could be a little bit noisy during peak times, but that can't really be helped.

review_title: Great place to work for students
job_title: Technical Support Representative in Moscow, ID
pros:
-My boss always accommodated school schedules and built our work schedules around it. Even allowing us to skip work for finals or tests. 
-Very easy to progress in the company. There are often openings for higher up positions and they prioritize hiring from within the company. 
-All other employees are wonderful to work with.
-Pay is very competitive for the area.
cons:
There are really no cons to working here. 
It is the ideal job for anyone going to school, but maybe not for someone that is not. Though there are plenty of higher up positions that are.

review_title: Small college feel, talented professors, loyal alumni
pros: Small college feel, talented professors, loyal alumni, two college towns side-by-side (Moscow, ID; Pullman, WA) that are like an oasis in what is otherwise a conservative area.
cons: Conservative state = always living on a constrained budget: Rarely a meaningful raise or increased budget from the legislature/governor, even when the economy is strong, because 'we need to put money away for a rainy day'; always a major budget cut (and occasionally a furlough) when the economy is weak, because 'we just don't have the tax revenue'. Don't expect market salary or healthy travel/research/teaching budgets to ever arrive.

pros: Beautiful campus, strong student-focused programs, helpful and friendly staff at all UI locations, located in the quaint city of Moscow, Idaho.
cons: Bureaucratic, lacking strong professional development program for staff, low compensation (but this is a problem statewide in Idaho), administration lacks trust in the work of their subordinates (evidenced by the number of rules and policies)

pros: There is a lot of support for student workers, seems to be a good jumping off point for a lot of people, including headcoaches and admin. If you are in STEM or athletics, there is a lot of focus on these two fields.
cons: The administration seems short sided, doesn't look for sustainable growth, seems overly focused on a mediocre at best football team.

pros: It was a very good and nice place to work. The senior management was very good a letting every one know and sometimes participate in decision making
cons: I wish they would provide more room for staff to take on some personal and social life activities such as being able to take time off to attend to family issues

review_title: Great place to foster teamwork, unless supervisor insists on control of every aspect
pros: Great co-workers, very much a community feel, and it is always nice to be working with students to advance the university's missions.
cons: Convoluted, complicated and confusing organization chart. When things go south, nobody will own up to it, and the blame gets shifted to whoever just left most recently.

review_title: Strategic Decisions Limit Abilities to Improve
pros: The city of Moscow is wonderful if you have family.  The hours and flexibility are great.  Beautiful campus.  Great students.
cons: Horrible pay.  The university seems to have no plan about who gets promoted into leadership positions and this ends up limiting UI growth and improvement.  Poor hiring decisions and weak leadership ends up wasting really valuable human resources.

pros: The people at the University of Idaho are very nice and they try to be helpful.  Additionally, the work environment is clean and the campus is comfortable.
cons: The incompetency of the people who work here is sometimes astonishing.  Not to mention that the location of the school in Idaho is hard to bare.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros:
Typical University town. Moscow is a great place to live in. Besides, it's a good place to raise kids and is generally family friendly.
The samll nature of the programs in the University of Idaho aids cooperation within interested parties. It's a good place for learning with serene surrounding and unbeatable calm.
cons: The pay is too low. As a teaching assistant, you femd for your health insurance, pay off a significant amount of your tuition costs and the work load could be horrible - just to say the least.

job_title: Social Media Coordinator in Moscow, ID
pros: I worked at the University of Idaho in a work-study capacity as well as a part-time social media coordinator. Both jobs always put my education first and allowed me to safely gain experience in many fields necessary for my career path.
cons: Funding isn't alway available for part-time positions in the summer even though you often have to spend most of the summer planning for projects and events as soon as the students arrive.

review_title: Well intentioned university with hard working faculty, staff, and students (and a budget shortfall).
pros: This university is a land grant research intensive institution, and there is plenty to be proud of here.  There is an air of hard work and forward progress, and a lot of constituents that simply care.
cons: The budget is tight... always.  Many people take on roles that are often reserved for 1.5 to 3 people at other institutions, and as with almost any large organization the bureaucratic structure runs deep.

review_title: I work as an Extension Ag Economist in the department of Agricultural Economics and Rural Sociology.
job_title: Extension Ag Economist in Moscow, ID
pros: This is a small, friendly place to work, with many dedicated young faculty. Work atmosphere is not too pressurized, particularly since I'm working as a support staff.
cons: Pay scale is quite low. Little flexibility for telecommuting. No upward mobility despite having a PhD.

pros:
- Compassionate, engaged management in the Writing Center
- Great experience for both tutors and students
- Professional, respectable environment
- Tutors genuinely care about the success of their students
cons: - Needs to be better funded by the university

pros:
Small, so you can meet mostly everyone, learn the system and do bigger projects
Room for innovation
Cool events to go to and locals/alumni/guests to meet
Integrated into the community pretty well
cons:
Resistant to change
Often conservative
EXTREMELY slow to work with faculty senate!!!--worst part
Idaho State Board of Ed is pretty horrible
Small budget at many levels
Skewed priorities
Don't comply with Title 9 very well

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Idaho Falls, ID
pros: Hands on research, management and staff are very interactive, good on the job training (helped me learn Chemical Engineering), opportunities to advance and collaborate with other teams.
cons: I happened to have a professor/supervisor who wasn't the best; this negatively impacted my personal experience. Fortunately the university and lab staff and faculty were understanding of my research group's situation and helped those affected the best they could.

pros:
Student employees
management team other than two highest positions
networking with university departments
student engagement
cons: The two highest managers micromanage their management team so much that nothing effective can be accomplished. Their ideas are always the "best" and though they claim to leave room for progress and innovation, this doesn't actually exist. In addition, they treat employees as if their lives outside of the job do not matter, and student/front line employees as if they are puppets.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: Good pay for Idaho, 10-12 per hour.  Variety of professors to work for, which gives many different interesting areas of research.
cons: Not all professors do a good job of mentoring students.  There is not as much funding at this school as larger ones, so equipment availability is limited.

pros: Caring faculty and staff with a beautiful campus. Can do attitude. Willingness to change. Hardworking students who go the extra mile.
cons: Low pay esp. for staff. Increase in the number of upper administrator's salaries without a significant increase in faculty and staff salaries. Hilly campus.

review_title: Poor salary, they want yes men.
pros: Nice people, but they are frustrated by the University
cons:
College of Life Science should be avoided.
They hire temps for years to avoid paying  benefits
Your co-workers have little skills but play the game.
Do across the border to Washington and get a real job
Faculty is payed 6 figures and staff make Big Box store wages

pros: Nothing quite like government style benefits in a cheap university town.  Also, nice people in a less corporate setting.  Also a steady back beat of "go team(s)" which makes for a steady beat of camadrie.
cons: Rather than a steady surge of busy, workload follows the academic year, becoming especially sharp and pronounced around registration and, of course, recruitment.  Also, certain individuals are insanely overworked at these times.

pros: Time off in summer is easy to come by.
cons:
Bureaucracy often promotes incompetence that sticks around rather than merit.
Since it is state run, most people entrenched in their positions will stick around, barring advancement.
Absolutely terrible pay, benefits only go to a fraction of positions.
Performance reviews are meaningless and they will promise raises possible, but they often have pay freezes for years at a time.

review_title: Get Paid for Doing Your Own Research or Teaching
job_title: Ph D Candidate in Moscow, ID
pros: Professional, helpful, they pay on time, reliable
cons: Not great technical resources in my area, my professor was too busy to teach me almost anything. Not much flexibility, insufficient remote resources, lots of rich foreign students, but poor inclusion of US diverse populations.

pros: Excellent quality of students and colleagues alike. Does an excellent job of serving current students as well as the state of Idaho. Solid benefits package as well.
cons: Has gone through multiple iterations of questionable upper level management, but current president seems to be a step forward (President Green).

review_title: Great culture and campus; Needs competitive compensation
job_title: Career Services Advisor in Moscow, ID
pros: The University of Idaho is a beautiful place to work with a small town, intimate culture. Benefits are quite decent for full-time employees, with reasonable options for accruing PTO/sick leave and HSA options.
cons: Compensation is not competitive, but they are currently working on a plan to improve this. Just hoping it won't take 5 years to implement.

review_title: U of I Tech Position Was Rewarding, Administration Was Frustrating
job_title: Virtual World Technician in Moscow, ID
pros: Exciting research involvement. Opportunity to learn a ton in a short time. I was able to apply my education. Salary was competitive and improved quickly.
cons: Contracts and wages were poorly managed by admins, resulted in many cases of significantly reduced pay.  Kept going back on oral obligations and created some financial distress.

pros: In the department I worked in I was able to shift my hours around if I had an appointment; I was able to get my hourly wage raised frequently over the course of a few years working there
cons: online training program and online system isn't very up to date and can be hard to use

pros: The pay is decent. The hours are flexible. It's a great place to work and I get a ton of experience.
cons: I haven't experienced any downsides in my position, but everything depends entirely on your lab's culture.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Moscow, ID
pros: I really enjoyed my time at The University of Idaho. It is a small school but with a strong biology department, where everyone is excited and willing to collaborate in new projects.
cons: The pay is a bit low for a graduate student but it's offset by the low cost of living in Moscow, ID.

pros: Free Starbucks leftovers... there were some fun co workers who were very helpful considering I was not given any formal trianing.
cons: Schedule never made more than 2 days prior to work, no training, no direction, no projects, a lot of time standing around and fixing clothing just to look like you are busy.

pros: Relaxed, easy going atmosphere. Lots of room for growth for a young employee. Lots of opportunity to learn new skills and participate in a wide range of projects. Easy and flexible working hours allow for plenty of family time.
cons: Low pay and very little pay increase. High level bureaucracy can slow things down considerably.

job_title: Student Energy Auditor in Moscow, ID
pros: This DOE sponsored program has been very educational in energy efficiency and industrial manufacturing. The University Faculty involved are very supportive and want us to succeed.
cons: The only downside I would say is that the program is currently very small, we would love to expand our influence throughout the university.

review_title: OK place to work, if you're a student.
pros:
Flexible hours
Good workplace environment (casual)
Open and welcoming atmosphere
cons:
Lack of transparency with some aspects of the organization, namely the administration.
Extremely difficult to move "up the chain" if you're a student.
Pay is not aligned to cost of living

pros: It is good University to work there. There are friendly environment as well as co-operative people. And we can easily learn the number of things there.
cons: I was working there for short time of period so, i didn't find any cons.

pros: In my department, there was wonderful people! Also got to take university classes for $5 a credit hour after 5 months
cons: Pay increases on merit rarely happen. There is usually a 2% cost of living adjustment each year though.

job_title: Annual Giving Caller in Moscow, ID
pros: It is a fun and rewarding place to work with a great team environment with opportunities for advancement and incentives.
cons: The work is monotonous and at times becomes boring. Depends a lot on the calling pool they are pulling from and if those called are receptive.

review_title: A good fit for some people, but not others.
pros: The location is beautiful. People are friendly. Cost of living is low.
cons: Upper management often appears disorganized, location is very isolated.

review_title: If only the Administrators cared about anything besides their own careers.
job_title: Assistant Professor Clinical Faculty in Moscow, ID
pros: Students and employees are for most part kind humans
cons: Stated does not support higher education, central administrators are disconnected from employees and students.

pros: This position allowed me the opportunity to interact with pre-college children and get them exited for a profession in Electrical Engineering.
cons: The lead instruction for the program was unreliable and unorganized. He would often act immature and inappropriate.

pros: I loved the variety of work I got to do and I loved how the Extension programs helped the local community.
cons: Sometimes there were more events running than staff to coordinate them, but everyone handled the stress well.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: Decent health insurance, friendly campus environment, everything in a walking distance, beautiful landscape, interesting projects, benefits for students and staff, good management.
cons: Salary rate which is quite low for a graduate student so it could be raised. Not too many career opportunities, however.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: Freedom in research, you get your tuition waived - which is a huge plus.
cons: Not great payment, barely covers daily expenses. Flexibility depends a lot on your supervisor. Some supervisors think they own your life.

review_title: It's been a great place to work.
job_title: Administrative Specialist in Coeur d'Alene, ID
pros: Amazing benefits, hands off management style.
cons: The politics involved in folks above my pay-grade can be felt and I a little exhausting at times.

review_title: The second best University within 20 miles
job_title: Electronic Technician, Electrical Engineering in Moscow, ID
pros: Flexible Hours and great coworkers
cons: No benefits, low pay, and poor prospects for advancement

review_title: So much potential, such little wages.
pros: Great people at the customer service level
cons: Run by a bunch of good ol boys.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: Cheap and very friendly atmosphere. This is a great place to raise kids and very family oriented town.
cons: At this moment, I cannot think of any cons, except the harsh winter during the winter

pros: Great experience that will carry into career of any type. Work around school schedule and build network with people on campus
cons: Inconvenient times and demanding job for student.

review_title: It was a wonderful experience to explore a new direction.
pros: Quiet, reliable, supportive, community, scenic location and very affectionate staff.
cons: Too many online classes, less interaction with students.

pros: nice location, great culture, people in general are nice
cons: people are unwilling to change, huge gaps between senior and junior faculties in salary, benefit and work life balance. No room to move up

pros: Good benefits (reduced tuition), good work/life balance, nice campus.
cons: Lack of accountability, bad employees are tolerated for far too long, hiring takes forever, lots of bureaucracy, poor salary, no upward mobility

review_title: Good to work there part time
pros: It is a good environment to work part time, friendly people and managers that will help you if you need help.
cons: Not any to say for now

pros: Very good program in a small school. Quality of teaching and research is high.
cons: Small town, far from major cities. Not a lot of jobs available in town after graduation.

job_title: Area Extension Educator in Twin Falls, ID
pros: Freedom to specialize, constantly learning, serving your community, lots of benefit including vacation
cons: Government education does not pay well.  You cannot support a family as a single household income.

pros: Great way to make some money as a student. You have options to travel and make your own schedule/projects.
cons: Out of state only students can work given the budget.

pros: Flexible schedule and working time. Working at the University of Idaho is not stressful.
cons: The only weak point for working at the University of Idaho, as a postdoc, is low salary.

job_title: Control Room Operator in Moscow, ID
pros: Really nice supervisors, easy to learn, very organized and helpful when needing work covered.
cons: Super boring, repetitive tasks, literally could fall asleep on the job.

pros: low humidity, unfriendly winter, somewhat harsh summer
cons: friendly environment, good for studies and research, good to raise family, inexpensive cost of living

job_title: Research Support Specialist in Moscow, ID
pros: Good benefits, great people, and clam and quite place to live.
cons: Nothing significant,  if you enjoy quite place this is a right place for you.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: The teamwork is exceptional. I have the chance to work with a very professional and collaborative team.
cons: I don't believe I have had a bad experience while working here

pros: Long tradition of excellence in education
cons: Challenges in attracting Idaho residents to aspire to and pla for a university education

pros: friendly environment,  good to make connections and improve communication skills
cons: minimum wage but you don't have to work hard so it is a fair price.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: Great understanding of skills for college-age students and great learning environment to encourage growth in leadership, technology skills and overall development.
cons: no cons at this time

review_title: Great place to learn, not a lot of opportunity
pros: Great place to learn more, and an encouraging environment.
cons: Not a huge pay range, and not a lot of advancement.

pros: Benefits and it is a great way to earn boiler operating license.
cons: The pay is not necessarily the best.

pros: Flexible hours, covers cost of living, friendly staff
cons: No benefits, Very Bureaucratic, Chuck Staben is a career politician.

pros: Awesome Faculty and resources for educators.
cons: Too much work load for the pay as with most adjunct positions.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: You get improve your knowledge with vast pool of questions from students
cons: No cons until, when this review was written

review_title: Ok - if you don't mind living in a very rural area
pros: Fairly competitive pay (for academia)
cons: Very rural area (could be a pro for some)

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: Professors are always ready to help you! A great place to work.
cons: None I can think of

pros: The environment is great for encouraging discussion and learning
cons: Lots of red tape and regulations, but is such with a university environment

pros: Moscow is a great town. The school isn't too big.
cons: Not as much research money as other schools. Slow application and hiring process.

job_title: Associate Director in Idaho Falls, ID
pros: Small expectations from the university
cons: There are small minded managers

job_title: Senior Level Instructor in Moscow, ID
pros: Teaching construction Documents and design
cons: Red lining and grading work done by students.  It was exausting.

job_title: IT Support Specialist in Moscow, ID
pros: good work place environment to learn new things
cons: pay is a little low compared to some other schools

pros: Friendly Environment of the University of Idaho is great.
cons: Cultural diversity is limited in the University of Idaho.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Moscow, ID
pros: very comfortable environment, Perfect for people who want a quiet and healthy life.
cons: not so many researchers to meet and collaborate

pros: Friendly, caring staff that are quick to respond to requests
cons: Low pay, not enough hours to depend on the job

pros: Wonderful people to work with, housing paid for, places to explore, increase your grass ID skills
cons: Sometimes a little bit boring

pros: Nice supervisor, flexible hours and friendly working environment
cons: Limited professional training. Most of time you gotta learn from your co-workers

job_title: Sign Language Interpreter in Moscow, ID
pros: Great campus to work in
cons: Long distance to commute from Rathdrum to Moscow...(1000 miles a week)

pros: flexible with my class schedule
cons: Sometimes not enough to do and not allowed to work on homework during down time.

pros: Great Team and very friendly atmosphere
cons: Lack of communication from senior leadership, poor budget decisions and lack of succession planning

pros: Good to work with this company.
cons: I do not see cons.

pros: plenty of resources in WSU and U of I
cons: Some faculty members are not supportive.

review_title: I love the University of Idaho!
job_title: Director of Development in Boise, ID
pros: Great institution with a great mission.
cons: Slow to get anything done and resistant to change.

review_title: Pleasant especially because they love to promote within
pros: Friendly atmosphere, small town charm
cons: Several incompetent individuals currently holding leadership positions

pros: Great people and leadership. Hub of culture and life experience.
cons: Too many people to make happy

review_title: A quiet place to do research
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Twin Falls, ID
pros: A quiet place to do research
cons: It is a OK place. Depends on your needs.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Idaho Falls, ID
pros: Supportive colleagues, good work-life balance, and competitive salary and benefits.
cons: Budget challenge, decline enrollment, and not stable leadership.

job_title: Human Resources Business Partner in Moscow, ID
pros: Good benefits, senior leaders are good to work with
cons: Gossip and childish behavior, poor salary and tiny town

pros: Excellent campus to work on with excellent faculty and researchers.
cons: lack of career mobility for students.

pros: Good networking opportunities. Great campus with talented professors.

pros: Great work environment and experience

pros: Knowledgable faculty, flexible hours, lots of learning opportunities.

pros: College level had a great community atmosphere.

pros: Nice and friendly environment. I like the town very much.

pros: good education and good support form most professors.

pros: Moscow is a good environment to raise a family

pros: Love the people, great job for college
cons: Not very competitive pay, but enough for bills.

pros: Great Benefits, and great culture

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Moscow, ID
pros: Beautiful location, go hiking, fishing, skiing.
cons: It can be a problem in snowy days

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Troy, NY
pros: Good work and life balance. Excellent  research opportunities.
cons: Overall university ranking is low.

pros: Small classes and helpful professors

pros: Good hours and good employer
